model.body_html:
Logan is cleaning his apartment. In particular, he must sort his old favorite sequence, , of positive integers in nondecreasing order. He's tired from a long day, so he invented an easy way (in his opinion) to do this job. His algorithm can be described by the following pseudocode:

while isNotSorted(P) do {   
    WaitOneMinute();
    RandomShuffle(P)
}

Can you determine the expected number of minutes that Logan will spend waiting for to be sorted?

Input Format

The first line contains a single integer, , denoting the size of permutation .
The second line contains space-separated integers describing the respective elements in the sequence's current order, .

Constraints

Output Format

Print the expected number of minutes Logan must wait for to be sorted, rounded to a scale of exactly decimal places (i.e., format).

Sample Input

2
5 2

Sample Output

2.000000

Explanation

There are two permutations possible after a random shuffle, and each of them has probability . The probability to get the sequence sorted after the first minute is . The probability that will be sorted after the second minute is , the probability will be sorted after the third minute is , and so on. So, the answer is equal to the following sum:

track.name: Algorithms
track.descriptions: The true test of problem solving: when one realizes that time and memory aren't infinite.

primary_contest.description:
Week of Code is a 7 day competition. From Monday through Friday, we’ll unlock one new challenge each day for you to solve. You’ll have the weekend (Saturday and Sunday) to complete any challenges you might have missed. 

The objective for this contest is to maintain your leaderboard status by solving all challenges in 7 days. We’ll send you a quick reminder each day to keep you on track. The top 10 hackers on the leaderboard win exclusive HackerRank T-shirts.
primary_contest.name: Week of Code 21

model.preview: How much time  will it take to sort a sequence?
model.name: Lazy Sorting
